title: AST to Platelet Ratio Index (APRI)
description: Determines the likelihood of hepatic fibrosis and cirrhosis in patients with hepatitis C using readily available laboratory values.

parameters.name: ast_upper_limit
parameters.description: Upper limit of normal for AST (typically 40 U/L for males, 32 U/L for females, or laboratory-specific reference range)

result.name: apri_score
result.description: APRI score calculated from AST and platelet values

ranges.interpretation: APRI ≤0.3 has high negative predictive value for excluding significant liver fibrosis (METAVIR F2-F4). Significant fibrosis is unlikely.
APRI 0.3-0.5 suggests low probability of advanced fibrosis. Values ≤0.5 have good negative predictive value for ruling out cirrhosis.
APRI 0.5-1.5 represents intermediate risk. Additional assessment with other non-invasive markers or liver biopsy may be needed for accurate staging.
APRI ≥1.5 has good positive predictive value for significant fibrosis (METAVIR F3-F4). Consider hepatology referral and surveillance for complications.
APRI ≥2.0 strongly suggests cirrhosis (METAVIR F4). Requires hepatology evaluation, surveillance for hepatocellular carcinoma, and assessment for portal hypertension complications.

references: Wai CT, Greenson JK, Fontana RJ, et al. A simple noninvasive index can predict both significant fibrosis and cirrhosis in patients with chronic hepatitis C. Hepatology. 2003;38(2):518-26.

Shaheen AA, Myers RP. Diagnostic accuracy of the aspartate aminotransferase-to-platelet ratio index for the prediction of hepatitis C-related fibrosis: a systematic review. Hepatology. 2007;46(3):912-21.

Lin ZH, Xin YN, Dong QJ, et al. Performance of the aspartate aminotransferase-to-platelet ratio index for the staging of hepatitis C-related fibrosis: an updated meta-analysis. Hepatology. 2011;53(3):726-36.
formula: APRI = [(AST/AST upper limit of normal) × 100] / Platelet count (×10³/µL)
notes: Originally developed and validated in hepatitis C patients
APRI has better negative predictive value than positive predictive value
Low APRI scores are reliable for ruling out cirrhosis, but APRI is less sensitive for identifying cirrhosis
Consider using in combination with other non-invasive markers for improved accuracy
May be less accurate in patients with acute hepatitis, portal hypertension, or other causes of thrombocytopenia
The AST upper limit of normal may vary by laboratory (commonly 40 U/L for males, 32 U/L for females)
